text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English 
with Jennifer. Do you like adventure?

Have you had some adventures in your life? I'm 
talking about the kinds of experiences that

allow you to break from the usual 
routine, place you in new environments,

and introduce you to new challenges. Quick story. 
After I graduated from college, I took another few

months to complete my teacher training. By then, I 
was feeling a little burned out, so I took a break

from academia to figure out my next step, which 
eventually would be graduate school. Between my

undergraduate and graduate work, I had a couple 
of adventures in the cruise line industry.
Let me tell you a bit more about the work I did,

and I'll help you develop a stronger 
sense of word order with prepositions.

We're going to complete a series of tasks 
that will check and build your understanding.
Task A. Can you identify all the prepositions?
One. The first ship sailed to the Bahamas.
Two. I worked as a youth counselor.
Three. We had a staff of a dozen counselors or so.

Four. Long hours on my feet 
were hard, but the work was fun.

Five. I was also a costume character, and I 
silently greeted passengers behind my mask.
Here are the prepositions.
And here are their objects.

Together they form prepositional phrases, and 
they can function like adverbs or adjectives.

These prepositional phrases modify nouns. 
They're descriptive like adjectives.
These prepositional phrases modify verbs,

and they give information such as 
direction and manner, just like adverbs.

Very often you'll see a prepositional phrase 
towards the end of a clause or a sentence.

That's because two very common sentence 
patterns are subject + verb + adverbial
and subject + verb + object + adverbial.

But prepositional phrases can have other 
positions. A sentence can start with an adverbial.

We might have a prepositional 
phrase as part of the subject.

And prepositional phrases 
can function as complements.

Task B. Where would you place 
the prepositional phrases?

Place comes before time, so I can say, "I 
got to relax on the beach in my free time.

This prepositional phrase marks the time, and 
I can place it in an initial or final position.

Within a couple of months, I got a nice dark tan. 
I got a nice dark tan within a couple of months.

If a place or time marker is important, I may 
choose that initial position to emphasize it.

A general guideline is that a prepositional 
phrase closely follows the word it modifies.

And remember not to separate a transitive verb 
from the direct object. Place a prepositional

phrase after the object. So I'll say, "I 
made friends from different countries."

Remember to keep prepositional phrases 
close to the words they modify.

When did I leave? I left that job after several 
months. Where did I go? I traveled to Russia.
Where did I volunteer? In an orphanage.

I left that job after several months because I 
wanted to travel to Russia and volunteer in an

orphanage. Or I can take the time marker and put 
it in the initial position: After several months,

I left that job because I wanted to travel 
to Russia and volunteer in an orphanage.

I told you we usually state place before time. 
We also tend to place manner before time.
Manner, place, time or duration.

O'll relive those memories 
with a smile for many years.

Remember we can have a few different 
prepositional phrases in a sentence,

but especially when you're writing, look for 
opportunities to be concise. Often a prepositional

phrase can be replaced. For example: For many 
years, I'll happily relive those memories.

Okay. Let's talk about a so-called 
rule that often gets broken.

We form a prepositional phrase with a preposition 
and an object. Right? With passengers. On a ship.
With whatever you want.
On it.

But there are times when we separate 
the preposition from its object,

and it sounds completely natural. You 
likely already do this in questions.

Nobody asks, "To whom do you wish to 
speak?" It's grammatically correct,

but it's very formal. In everyday English, 
we ask, "Who do you want to talk to?"

When we form a question in everyday English, we 
start with a question word, and a preposition

will stick close to the verb. What are 
you looking at? What do you need that for?

This is one reason why it's helpful to 
learn collocations. Collocations are common

combinations of words, like "look at something." 
"Need something for something."

I go over many collocations in 
my playlist on prepositions.

We also separate a preposition from 
its object in an adjective clause.

It's grammatically correct to use a 
preposition before a relative pronoun,

but it's only done in formal 
English, mainly in writing.

The ship on which I sailed catered 
to families with young children.

The ship I sailed on catered to 
families with young children.

Can you make this sentence sound 
more like everyday English?

The other crew members with whom I became friends 
were from North America, Asia, and Europe.

The other crew members I became friends with were 
from North America, Asia, and Europe. Notice how

I also chose to omit the relative pronoun because 
it's an object pronoun in an identifying clause.

You can see my playlist on adjective clauses 
to review how to use a relative pronoun.

So, sometimes separating a 
preposition from its object

is a matter of choice and a matter 
of register: formal or informal.

With passive verbs, this kind of separation 
is simply the way we word a sentence.

We start with the subject, and a 
preposition will stick close to the verb.

Some plans are only talked 
about, but never realized.

What's the subject? Some plans. 
And the verb? Are talked about.

Changing from active to passive, 
we can make an object the subject.

But we can't lose the preposition. 
The preposition will stick close to

the verb: are talked about. Another 
collocation. Talk about something.

The subject of the passive 
sentence still receives the action,

so the relationship with the 
preposition is still clear.

If you need to review passive voice, 
watch my lesson on active vs. passive.

Try this next short task. 
Make the sentences passive.
Change the verbs in bold from active to passive.

The cruise was paid for before 
the passengers came on board.

The crystal blue waters of the 
Bahamas are talked about quite a lot.

By the way, some sources have a name for 
when the preposition is separated from

its object. I first learned the term "stranded 
preposition." There's also "deferred preposition."

Recently, a viewer asked me about a "dangling 
preposition." So there's a third name. So,

we can have stranded, deferred, and dangling 
prepositions in questions, adjective clauses,

passive structures, and you'll also see the 
separation in a couple of other situations.

I can say, "It was too bright to look 
at the white sand on a sunny day.

Or I can move "white sand" 
to the front of the sentence

and look what happens. The white sand 
was too bright to look at on a sunny day.

I used fronting to emphasize sand, and as a 
result, I have a stranded preposition: at.
In that example, I'm also using an infinitive:

to look at. When we use infinitives and gerunds, 
we may end up with a stranded preposition.

Listen now. Listen for two more 
examples of stranded prepositions.

Once a passenger chatted with 
me about my future. She was an

older woman who had more life experience, 
and she wondered why I was sailing on a ship

when I could be pursuing my original passion: 
education. Her words were worth reflecting on.

She gave me something to think about. That's 
when I decided to apply to graduate school.
Her words were worth reflecting on.
She gave me something to think about.

Let's look at more examples to review all the 
patterns. Quickly spot the stranded preposition.
The second ship I worked on was much smaller.
The job I was hired for was very different.

My work as a gift shop purser was 
something I had never prepared for.

My free evenings were what I waited for all 
day. I was allowed to dance in the ballroom.
The men I danced with were polite and charming.

During the day, I went to the 
upper deck of the steamboat.

Towns I had only heard of passed before my eyes 
as we sailed up and down the Mississippi River.

What cities did we stop in? New Orleans, 
Natchez, Vicksburg, Memphis, St. Louis.
New Orleans is a city worth going back to.

Note in number eight "go back" is a phrasal 
verb. Sometimes phrasal verbs combine with

a prepositional phrase. "To" is a stranded 
preposition. Go back where? To New Orleans.
Adventure isn't something to long for. Seek it.
Name a goal you want to work towards.

Has your understanding of word 
order with prepositions grown?

I hope so. One tip is to read. Reading 
exposes you to grammatical structures,

and seeing them written gives 
you the chance to process them.

Fiction is a good choice because you get a mix 
of literary language and everyday dialogue. We'll

end here. Please like the video if you found the 
lesson useful. I hope you have some adventures,

and I look forward to having a few more of my own. 
As always, thanks for watching and happy studies!

Follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and 
Instagram. Why not join me on Patreon?
And don't forget to subscribe on YouTube!
